description:
Ebola is spread by contact with the fluids of an infected person, so these suits must be impervious to fluids. That means the venting system must be one-way only; vent from inside the suit to the outside.  One-way vents at shoulders and head will allow heated air out while staying sealed against incoming fluid.
But how do we move the air to the vents? By a foot pump in each boot. Design a boot  with a pump that pushes air upward with each step. 
The suit must be loose enough to allow air circulation. Think of the those worn by Muslim men. The long ankle-length robe of tropic weight fabric circulates air with every movement.
The air-pushing shoes, coupled with naturally circulating clothes with one-way vents gives a low-tech option that does not require energy systems.
summary: 1. Design or redesign footwear that pumps air upward with each step. Think of those Z-Coil shoes with a spring instead of a heel. Or the Reebok Pump.2. Use loose-fitting robes like the traditional Muslim throbe (made of a fabric impervious to fluids) that naturally circulates air with each movement. 3. Use one-way vents at shoulders and head to move hot air out of the clothes.
title: A FAN Base: Boot Up Those Suits
